keyTakeAways: India has denied any agreement with U.S. President Donald Trump to stop purchasing Russian oil.
India maintains that its energy policy prioritizes stable prices and diversified sourcing, including significant imports from Russia.
India's refusal to comply with U.S. pressure reflects a strategic assertion of national sovereignty and energy independence.
India's state-owned refiners have increased Russian oil purchases in recent months, indicating continued reliance on Russian supply.
U.S. tariffs on India (25% initial, 50% additional) are a key point of diplomatic friction, undermining trade relations.
India's diplomatic stance underscores its growing global role as a non-aligned, independent energy actor.
India and the U.S. are engaging in diplomatic efforts to resolve trade tensions, but no resolution is yet in place as of October 17, 2025.

summaryOfNewsArticle: U.S. President Donald Trump claimed that Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi had assured him India would stop importing Russian oil, a statement India has strongly denied. India’s foreign ministry spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal and the foreign ministry have stated they are unaware of any such conversation or assurance, emphasizing that India’s energy policy focuses on stable prices and diversified sourcing. India remains a major buyer of Russian oil, with state-owned refiners like Indian Oil Corporation Limited continuing to purchase significant volumes. Analysts note that a sudden halt is impractical due to volume, quality, and refinery compatibility issues. The dispute has led to a 50% U.S. tariff on Indian imports, contributing to strained U.S.-India trade relations. Despite the friction, both countries are engaged in diplomatic efforts to resolve the issue, highlighting India’s strategic autonomy in global energy and foreign policy.
title: India Denies Agreements to Stop Buying Russian Oil, Rejects Trump's Claims
